item.title: Bison Or Brian? From A Calorie Perspective, Cannibalism Didn't Pay For Paleo Humans
item.description: April 6, 2017 - Archaeological records show ancient humans sometimes ate each other. A new study suggests that hunting and eating other humans cost too much effort to be a regular thing. So why'd they do it?
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 6, 2017 - Archaeological records show ancient humans sometimes ate each other. A new study suggests that hunting and eating other humans cost too much effort to be a regular thing. So why'd they do it? http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/04/06/522880018/what-s-the-dietary-value-of-a-human

item.title: CDC Issues New Warning On Zika Virus Ahead Of Mosquito Season
item.description: April 6, 2017 - NPR's Robert Siegel talks to Margaret Honein, co-leader for the CDC Zika Response Team's Pregnancy and Birth Defects Task Force, about the latest guidance on Zika at the start of mosquito season.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 6, 2017 - NPR's Robert Siegel talks to Margaret Honein, co-leader for the CDC Zika Response Team's Pregnancy and Birth Defects Task Force, about the latest guidance on Zika at the start of mosquito season. http://www.npr.org/2017/04/06/522903447/cdc-issues-new-warning-on-zika-virus-ahead-of-mosquito-season

item.title: In Giant Virus Genes, Hints About Their Mysterious Origin
item.description: April 6, 2017 - They're the Godzillas of the virus world, pushing the limit of what is considered alive. Researchers are trying to figure out where they came from. (And no, they aren't known to make people sick.)
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 6, 2017 - They're the Godzillas of the virus world, pushing the limit of what is considered alive. Researchers are trying to figure out where they came from. (And no, they aren't known to make people sick.) http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/04/06/522478901/in-giant-virus-genes-hints-about-their-mysterious-origin

item.title: Fentanyl Adds A New Terror For People Abusing Opioids
item.description: April 6, 2017 - People who abuse opioids are well aware of the risk posed by fentanyl, a powerful anesthetic that's increasingly slipped into heroin and other drugs. They're coming up with new tactics to survive.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 6, 2017 - People who abuse opioids are well aware of the risk posed by fentanyl, a powerful anesthetic that's increasingly slipped into heroin and other drugs. They're coming up with new tactics to survive. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/04/06/521248448/fentanyl-adds-a-new-terror-for-people-abusing-opioids

item.title: How Flawed Science Is Undermining Good Medicine
item.description: April 6, 2017 - U.S. taxpayers pay $30 billion a year to fund biomedical research aimed at finding better treatments. But competition for scarce funding and tenure may be prompting some scientists to cut corners.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 6, 2017 - U.S. taxpayers pay $30 billion a year to fund biomedical research aimed at finding better treatments. But competition for scarce funding and tenure may be prompting some scientists to cut corners. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/04/06/522262881/how-flawed-science-is-undermining-good-medicine

item.title: Why Children Face The Greatest Danger From Chemical Weapons
item.description: April 5, 2017 - The effects of such weapons are more devastating for a number of reasons. And if children survive, they suffer from the trauma of the attack for far more years because they have more years to live.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 5, 2017 - The effects of such weapons are more devastating for a number of reasons. And if children survive, they suffer from the trauma of the attack for far more years because they have more years to live. http://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/04/05/522761057/why-children-face-the-greatest-danger-from-chemical-weapons

item.title: Emergency Room Doctors Are Picking Noses — For Drug Delivery, That Is
item.description: April 5, 2017 - Nasal versions of sedatives and overdose drugs are increasingly popular in emergency departments. Doctors like that they act quickly and don't require an IV to administer.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 5, 2017 - Nasal versions of sedatives and overdose drugs are increasingly popular in emergency departments. Doctors like that they act quickly and don't require an IV to administer. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/04/05/522735518/emergency-room-doctors-are-picking-noses-for-drug-delivery-that-is

item.title: How Diabetes Got To Be The No. 1 Killer In Mexico
item.description: April 5, 2017 - Diabetes has become a public health crisis in Mexico. The government is struggling to pay for care and slow the rate at which people develop the life-threatening metabolic disorder.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 5, 2017 - Diabetes has become a public health crisis in Mexico. The government is struggling to pay for care and slow the rate at which people develop the life-threatening metabolic disorder. http://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/04/05/522038318/how-diabetes-got-to-be-the-no-1-killer-in-mexico

item.title: Do You Zone Out? Procrastinate? Might Be Adult ADHD
item.description: April 5, 2017 - Six questions like "How often do you procrastinate?" can help doctors identify adults with ADHD, researchers say. They estimate that the disorder impairs daily functions for about 8 percent of adults.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 5, 2017 - Six questions like "How often do you procrastinate?" can help doctors identify adults with ADHD, researchers say. They estimate that the disorder impairs daily functions for about 8 percent of adults. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/04/05/522711509/do-you-zone-out-procrastinate-might-be-adult-adhd

item.title: Do U.S. Troops Risk Brain Injury When They Fire Heavy Weapons?
item.description: April 5, 2017 - Some modern shoulder-fired weapons produce blast waves powerful enough to rattle the brain. A $30 million study aims to help the military figure out how much blast exposure, over time, is too much.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 5, 2017 - Some modern shoulder-fired weapons produce blast waves powerful enough to rattle the brain. A $30 million study aims to help the military figure out how much blast exposure, over time, is too much. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/04/05/522613294/do-u-s-troops-risk-brain-injury-when-they-fire-heavy-weapons

item.title: Judges Take Up Big Soda's Suit To Abolish Philadelphia's Sugar Tax
item.description: April 5, 2017 - An appeals court hears arguments Wednesday on the future of Philly's landmark tax on sweetened drinks. The money is funding preschool for low-income kids, but the soda industry says it's losing jobs.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 5, 2017 - An appeals court hears arguments Wednesday on the future of Philly's landmark tax on sweetened drinks. The money is funding preschool for low-income kids, but the soda industry says it's losing jobs. http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/04/05/522626223/judges-take-up-big-sodas-suit-to-abolish-philadelphias-sugar-tax

item.title: Broth-Loving Hipsters Are Pushing Up The Price Of Bones
item.description: April 4, 2017 - With bone broth mania sweeping parts of the U.S. (we see you, LA), cheap bones are harder to come by. Some broth makers are moving away from the standard beef and chicken to new bones — like alpaca.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 4, 2017 - With bone broth mania sweeping parts of the U.S. (we see you, LA), cheap bones are harder to come by. Some broth makers are moving away from the standard beef and chicken to new bones — like alpaca. http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/04/04/522190305/broth-loving-hipsters-are-pushing-up-the-price-of-bones

item.title: Citing Abortions In China, Trump Cuts Funds For U.N. Family Planning Agency
item.description: April 4, 2017 - The administration claims the U.N. population agency supports China's "coercive" abortion policies. UNFPA calls the claim "erroneous."
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 4, 2017 - The administration claims the U.N. population agency supports China's "coercive" abortion policies. UNFPA calls the claim "erroneous." http://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/04/04/522040557/citing-abortions-in-china-trump-cuts-funds-for-u-n-family-planning-agency

item.title: 51 Babies Born With Zika-Related Birth Defects In The U.S. Last Year
item.description: April 4, 2017 - The Zika virus continues to impact a small number of pregnant women and their babies in the U.S., and there is no sign of it slowing down. "Zika is here to stay," the CDC's acting director says.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 4, 2017 - The Zika virus continues to impact a small number of pregnant women and their babies in the U.S., and there is no sign of it slowing down. "Zika is here to stay," the CDC's acting director says. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/04/04/522569622/51-babies-born-with-zika-related-birth-defects-in-the-u-s-last-year

item.title: Taking Shortcuts In Drug Testing Can Put Patients At Risk
item.description: April 4, 2017 - Researchers use intermediate endpoints like how a drug lowers cholesterol to get a quick sense of whether the drug might improve health. But those shortcuts often don't show true benefits and harms.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 4, 2017 - Researchers use intermediate endpoints like how a drug lowers cholesterol to get a quick sense of whether the drug might improve health. But those shortcuts often don't show true benefits and harms. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/04/04/522583228/taking-shortcuts-in-drug-testing-can-put-patients-at-risk
